danish_publication: Tæt öst for Höje by i Lunde sogn, findes en stor grusbanke, som man kalder Gammelhöj. Her boede en gang en bjærgmand, og han hentede en kone i nabolaget ind i Gammelhöj for at svøbe börn. Da konen var færdig dermed og skulde hjem, gav bjærgmanden hende et forklædefuldt kul. Konen mente ikke, det var umagen værd at bære dem hjem, og kastede dem derfor fra sig udenfor. Men da hun kom hjem, så hun til sin forundring og ærgrelse, at det var guld, bjærgmanden havde givet hende for ulejligheden, ti der hang endnu en del guldstøv i forklædet.
english_publication: Just to the east of Høje town in Lunde parish there's a large gravel mound they call Gammelhøj (Old Mound). A mound man lived there once and he brought a woman in the neighborhood into the mound to swaddle children. When the woman was finished and was to go home, the mound man gave her an apron full of coal. The woman didn't think it was worth the trouble to carry it home, and so she threw it away outside. But when she got home, much to her surprise and disappointment, she saw that it was gold that the mound man had given her for her inconvenience, since there was still a little gold dust clinging to her apron.
